Award.AwardTitle: An investigation of plasma formation in electromechanically driven free bubbles at resonance in water with applications for the treatment of water

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1336375
Foster

Current water treatment methodologies are not designed to handle emerging contamination threats derived from agricultural run-off, volatile organic compounds, and pharmaceutical residues therefore advanced methods are needed. Plasma production in liquid water produces a host of oxidation agents capable of rapidly decomposing organic contaminants. The proposed effort investigates a novel method of producing plasma in bubbles immersed in water by driving them at resonance in the presence of an electric field. This effort studies the ignition physics of resonantly driven bubbles, the time evolution of plasma formation in such bubbles, and the chemistry of the active interfacial layer separating the plasma bubble and the liquid water. The understanding gained from these studies will be used to design and build a plasma reactor for the purpose of water purification. Laboratory tours and demonstrations will be given to students from the Detroit Area Pre-College Engineering Program and those sponsored by Women in Science and Engineering, using in-house fabricated plasma demonstration experiments. The proposed effort will sponsor a student from the Summer Research Opportunity Program (SROP), a program aimed at encouraging underrepresented students to attend graduate school. The plasma demonstrations will be integrated into the existing educational outreach effort led by the National Society of Black Engineers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Water can be decontaminated of toxic chemicals, bacteria, and virus particles  by exposing it to plasma. Plasma in contact with water generates reactive oxygen and reactive nitrogen species that degrades organic contaminants into carbon dioxide and water. Plasma formation in water normally takes place in gas bubbles. The goal of this research was to understand mechansims of plasma formation in bubbles in water with the end goal of utilizing this understanding to introduce methods to reduce voltage requirements for breakdown of bubble in water as well as translate this knowledge into a working water purification apparatus. This effort has led to the development of an apparatus that allowed for the study of breakdown phenomna in ultrasoncially trapped bubbles. This effort used this apparaus to study the effect of varying both the volume and shape of trapped bubbles on plasma formation voltage.  Variations in bubble shape and volume were carried out using a large, time varying electric field to harmonically stretch and compress the bubble.  Sound waves were also used to excited bubble oscillations.  In addition to shape and volume modes, surface wave oscilaltions, which also distorted the local electric field, were observed. The work showed that distorted bubbles could breakdown without making contact with the powered electrode.  The work also showed that self propagating discharges in water could initiate plasma formationin trapped bubbles thereby providing support to the notion that the plasma actually hops from bubble to bubble as it propagates through the liquid medium.  This work led to the development of an low frequency plasma jet that could operate with or without air flow.  The plasma jet demostrated the capacity to rapidly degrade organic contanminats in solution.  The device could effectively degrade chemicals without producing nitrites or nitrates in solution. In addition to the plasma jet, the fundamental understanding gained from this study allowed for the development of a second plasma water purifier that shows great promise for scaleup and ultimately for use in high throughput water treatment faciltities. This effort has enabled the prospect of commercializing these technologies.  The plasma based treatment technology developed under this grant is a potential solution for the treatment of water slated for reuse in industrial settings as well as for those municipal water reuse, particularly in drought stricken areas. Water reuse makes both businesses and muncipalities resilient against those conditions that can lead to reduced freshwater availability such as climate change, overpopulation, overdevelopment, and pollution.
